trial_identification.studytitle: The effectiveness of xylocaine spray in upper gastrointestinal endoscopy
trial_identification.scientifictitle: The effect of 10% xylocaine spray compared to a placebo on ease of endoscopy and hemodynamic changes in patients admitted for upper gastrointestinal endoscopy under deep sedation with total intravenous anesthesia

conditioncode.conditioncode2: Other diseases of the mouth, teeth, oesophagus, digestive system including liver and colon

interventions.interventions: Patients are randomly assigned to have 10% lidocaine spray (approximately 30mg) or normal saline in their throat on arrival, approximately 3 minutes before upper gastrointestinal endoscopy.
interventions.comparator: normal saline is sprayed onto patients throats before endoscopy

primaryOutcome.outcome: The overall ease of the endoscopy assessed by endoscopists via rating scales. Rating scales are used to assess by endoscopists. The parameters include patients' ability to follow verbal command, show somatic response after anesthesia, have any coughs, hiccups, or gag reflex on esophageal intubation and also the overall ease of esophageal intubation and satification of the procedure by endoscopists.
primaryOutcome.timepoint: at the end of the endoscopy

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Hemodynamic changes during endoscopy (eg heart rate, non-invasive blood pressure, oxygen saturation on 3L oxygen nasal prong, BIS index) and the requirement of airway maneuver
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: The hemodynamic values (HR, BP, BIS, SpO2) are recorded on arrival, then every 2 min afterwards during endoscopy and again on departure.

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: 1. All participants who sign the consent and agreement form 2. All participants who are admitted for upper gastrointestinal endoscopy under general anesthesia with total intravenous anesthesia 3. All participants who are between the age of 20 and 69
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: 1. young age <20 years; old age >69 years 2. participants who are reported to have allergic reaction to the anesthetic agents used in the study (lidocaine) 3. pregnant women or who are breastfeeding 4. participants who are deemed to have significant higher risk if enrolled in the study (eg severe obstructive sleep apnea)

trial_design.concealment: All patients who fullfill the inclusion criteria are recruited. The consented participants are allocated to have either lidocaine spray or normal saline spray sprayed onto their throat before the endoscopy via a central randomization by computer . Both the patients and endoscopists are blinded whereas the anesthetist on site is to administer the spray and is aware of the allocation.
trial_design.sequence: Simple randomisation using a randomisation table created by computer software

ethicsAndSummary.summary: The use of topical pharyngeal anesthesia has long been controversial among the anesthetists and no evidence has well supported the use of the spray. The use of lidocaine spray is not without adverse effects, which include aspiration pneumonia, methemoglobinemia and anaphylaxis. Most of the patients undergo endoscopies under general anesthesia and theoretically should not require pharngeal spray to suppress pharyngeal reflexes during the procedure. The aim of the study is determine whether the use of the spray is necessary in patients under deep sedation/general anesthesia. Deep sedation is achieved by total intravenous anesthesia (TIVA) with propofol.
